claim: Electronics have become more affordable in the US since 1990.

supporting.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has significantly decreased since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.

attacks.text: The average price of consumer electronics such as televisions, computers, and smartphones has significantly decreased since 1990 due to advancements in manufacturing and economies of scale.
While average prices have decreased, the overall cost of ownership has increased due to planned obsolescence and frequent upgrades required for compatibility with new software and services.
Planned obsolescence affects only certain segments of electronics, and many devices remain functional for years without requiring upgrades, especially in basic usage scenarios.
The decrease in average prices does not account for inflation-adjusted costs, which may show a less significant reduction in affordability.
Studies show that even after adjusting for inflation, the prices of key electronics like televisions and computers have fallen substantially due to technological advancements.
The focus on average prices ignores the widening gap between high-end and budget electronics, making advanced features less accessible to lower-income consumers.
Budget electronics today offer features comparable to high-end models from 1990, ensuring basic affordability and functionality for all income levels.

supporting.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that the cost of many electronic devices, including laptops and mobile phones, has declined since 1990 while their performance has improved.

attacks.text: Inflation-adjusted data shows that the cost of many electronic devices, including laptops and mobile phones, has declined since 1990 while their performance has improved.
The decline in prices is not uniform across all electronics; some high-end devices (e.g., GPUs, professional-grade equipment) have seen price increases due to demand surges and supply constraints.
Even high-end devices show long-term price-performance improvement when adjusted for inflation and technological advancement, making them effectively more affordable.
The affordability claim ignores hidden costs like mandatory software subscriptions, accessories, and planned obsolescence, which increase total ownership costs.
Studies show that even with add-ons, the total cost of ownership for electronics has decreased relative to income growth and inflation since 1990.

supporting.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down the prices of electronics in the US since 1990.

attacks.text: The proliferation of global supply chains and competition among manufacturers has driven down the prices of electronics in the US since 1990.
While competition has increased, rising tariffs and trade wars since 2018 have significantly increased the cost of imported electronics in the US.
The impact of tariffs is limited to specific product categories and has not reversed the overall long-term trend of declining electronics prices due to technological advancements.
Inflation-adjusted data shows that while nominal prices have decreased, real affordability has not improved significantly due to stagnant wage growth.
Wage stagnation affects purchasing power broadly, but electronics have still become relatively more affordable compared to other goods due to faster price declines.

supporting.text: Technological innovations and mass production have reduced the cost of components like semiconductors, making electronics more affordable for US consumers since 1990.

attacks.text: Technological innovations and mass production have reduced the cost of components like semiconductors, making electronics more affordable for US consumers since 1990.
While component costs have decreased, inflation-adjusted wages for many US consumers have stagnated or declined, offsetting affordability gains.
Product complexity and premium features have increased, leading to higher absolute prices for many electronics despite cheaper base components.
Supply chain disruptions and trade tariffs since 2018 have caused significant price increases for consumer electronics in the US market.
The CPI for consumer electronics shows a consistent 4-6% annual price decline since 1990 when accounting for quality improvements.
Even with wage stagnation, the time-price ratio (hours worked needed to purchase electronics) has improved dramatically due to efficiency gains.

supporting.text: The introduction of budget-friendly electronic brands and models since 1990 has expanded access to affordable technology for US households.

attacks.text: The introduction of budget-friendly electronic brands and models since 1990 has expanded access to affordable technology for US households.
While budget brands exist, inflation-adjusted prices for high-end electronics (e.g., flagship smartphones, GPUs) have risen significantly since 1990, offsetting affordability gains.
High-end electronics represent a small fraction of the market; most consumers prioritize mid-range or budget devices, which have seen consistent price declines.
The affordability claim ignores hidden costs like mandatory subscriptions (e.g., cloud storage, software licenses) that inflate total ownership expenses.
Many subscriptions are optional, and standalone functionality of budget devices often meets basic needs without additional costs.
